comments.commentBody: Futbolista; You had it right: Barca won three trophies this year: The European Super Cup, the Spanish Super Cup, and the Club World Championship

For how long have you lived in the Bay Area? Al Davis coined the phrase. He was the coach (first) then general manager, and then long time owner of the Oakland Raiders, and he coined it back in the 70s, when the Raiders were the best team in the NFL behind the Pittsburgh Steelers. He died last year. He wasn't big on picking up style points.
Jerome, yes, digital. According to her website she uses a Canon EOS 5D Mk2.

OK, if we're all done bragging about what we haven't read or seen, I'll put in another plug for The Girl With the Sturgeon Tattoo, which is a parody of the first Larsson book, both funnier, shorter, and with a better plot. Oops, that's three things.

Donald E. Westlake would have been happy with this one. Ukea is Sweden's national pressboard easy assembly furniture business (along with its other national business, Saab). Ukea is hiding a terrible terrible scandal - its early furniture items were designed by a budding young Austrian megalomaniacal mass murderer artist named Shickl ... oh, wait, don't want to give too much away.

Sweden is one of the more boring European countries, as well as perhaps the blondest. Both stereotypes permeate the book, like the dragon in today's puzzle, speaking of, which went a long way towards proving my unspoken but often thought thought that Tuesdays are easier than Mondays. Parse THAT, emus!

Deb, I won't steal your thunder (pun intended) with my own (well not mine, but someone I know) story about live mikes in bathrooms, only to say that it was a company sales conference and a few opinions of management were offered (orally).

The reason that Mr. Poppe's phone is not ringing off the hook (quaint) is that most boards are rubber stamps for management. Corporate governance is a laughable term. If the past five years have shown the public anything, it is the complete lack of accountability of CEO's and Boads for the reckless behavior that has characterized corporate leadership, especially in the financial sector. Stockholders, like voters, see the system as rigged. They do not vote or raise their voices because they do not wish to dignify the farce by their participation.
On to the next crisis.

A fascinating premise David and one that relies ultimately, if one aspires to be a successful monopolist, on having an idea, for whatever the product is that is unique, as you say, at least for a time.

Having spent more than fifty years in business, and having dreamed that it was possible to accomplish what Peter Theil has done, and never coming even close, I now wish that I was 22 again, and looking for the new and authentic product to bring to the marketplace.

Traditional competition is terrific and a lot of fun, though because of the nature of the marketplace no matter how one excels in the traditional business arena, success is difficult to develop and maintain unless the product is totally leading edge, again, at least for a time, as you said.. That is the key to the monopolist concept and where Peter Theil has done a fantastic job.

I look forward to learning more about him and his ideas. And I wish him, and those who are inventing the future today, the best of good fortune and lots of luck.

TTops are sports car body designs where (showing my ignorance of details) EITHER the roofs of the driver and passenger comartments lift off so you're left with kind of a Swedish convertible that's still a hardtop OR where the doors open up rather han sideways (I don't think those are TTOPS but they sound so silly I wanted to get them in too.

Anyway TTOPS are convertibles without the fun.

It's good that Andy recognizes that the Niners do not fit his pattern. In fact, I bet we would not see this article being written if Kyle Williams hadn't turned the ball over twice against the Giants.

When Harbaugh came to Stanford and inherited a 1-11 team, the college game was all about spread offenses, and it has continued to be that way. But Harbaugh went against the grain and installed a tough, physical, power-running, tight-end oriented version of the West Coast offense. On defense, he instituted an attacking 3-4 defense. That contrarian approach has resulted in two consecutive years of top 10 ranking for the Cardinal, and 3 consecutive Heisman finalists.

I won't be surprised that with the aging of Brady , Manning, and Brees, the all-QB approach may have peaked, with the Niners showing the way to an offensive system that relies less on a top-5 QB and more on schemes and a solid running game.

Our defense budget has made the longest period of economic growth in the history of the world--possible.

That budget is responsible for the umbrella of peace that made the agriculture revolution, the information revolution, the computer revolution, and many political revolutions possible as well. Revolutions that created more wealth, more medicine, more lives saved than even anti-biotics.

Are we currently spending 200B a year more on defense than is necessary? Yes. Is that an elephant in the room that will melt away the fiscal concerns of the world?

A contrarian, which I am not, would say, with basis; "Considering the state of the world, the over (200B) spending may turn out to be prudence."

I stubbornly on the high road----Make the economy more productive and it will reward you with the sweet milk of marginal wealth at every income level.

comments.userDisplayName: Variations on a Theme of Paul
comments.commentBody: Name something crazier.

No doubt the NFL is pass-happy and NBA players drivng the lane can expect more physical contact than QB's.

But the logic behind this post and the direct corellation between a star QB and rings is based on a ridiculously small sample size. Are Big Ben and Eli truly elite QB's or simply in that category because of the hardware? And in the copycat NFL all it takes is one Super Bowl victory by a "lesser" QB on an excellent team, like an Alex Smith or Joe Flacco to dsipell this myth. (But then the author would place them in the pantheon of elite, Super Bowl winning QB's to support this argument)

And, finally, if elite QB's are the silver bullet why has Peyton Mannng won only one ring? And why has Tom Brady suffered such a long dry spell? And why haven't stat-elite QB's Phillip Rivers and Tony Romo yet to appear in the big game?

There's no doubt the NFL is all about the passing game. But it's more about riding the hot hand of your QB in January and catching those few breaks in each playoff game that are the differençe betwen winning and losing. (see Giants, Packers, Steelers championship teams). Who knows? Next year that hot hand might belong to Mark Sanchez or even Tim Tebow. Crazier things have happened.

The reason that Mr. Poppe's phone is not ringing off the hook (quaint) is that most boards are rubber stamps for management. Corporate governance is a laughable term. If the past five years have shown the public anything, it is the complete lack of accountability of CEO's and Boads for the reckless behavior that has characterized corporate leadership, Bangladesh news especially in the financial sector. Stockholders, like voters, see the system as rigged. They do not vote or raise their voices because they do not wish to dignify the farce by their participation.
On to the next crisis.

JB I agree with your entire post except the full disclosure as applied to me.  I liked the books, but I like books about aging Nazis getting their comeuppance and militant (well maybe a bit beyond militant) feminists - oh wait, there's only one militant feminist in the books, the rest are meek women or editors.  The men (aging teenagers) are all computer hackers.
....and all nicely held aloft in balance by the author at the base.

Funny story, Deb. Sounds like the flushing at U.D. wasn't just you turning red.

Unless I've lost count, I've seen four of the movie adaptations and read the first of the books. No special knowledge of the story is needed to understand the title placement. The theme answers have left/right symmetry in the grid (allowing the full title to be read in sequence), and the black squares use regular crossword symmetry. That's a little unusual. The winding circled letters simulate the dragon tattoo. Nice visual effect. I liked it.

Josh, with manufacturing now at such a low percentage of GDP,where will the government place enough orders to truly matter? More weapon systems? Hamburgers?

That's why stoverny's points are so well taken.

Make sure the truly poor are cared for.

Then tax the wealthiest like it's 1958. Break up the largest fortunes with 100% tax on inheritances over $1,000,000. Tax capitals gains over $1,000,000 at the same progressive rate as income that high is taxed.

And as Seattle said above, share the pain in the middle class. Abolish the mortgage credit. Look at Medicare for everybody if that's cheaper. And look at social security reform, done in a way that doesn't break promises to those on or close to being on it. But the promise is security. No need to cry "it's my money!" if you already have WAY more than you need.

And yes, look at responsibly cutting the military.

What we need is leadership. Our best chance is in an Obama second term where he doesn't have to run again and Biden will be to old. Leadership in speaking directly to the people, enough to stir shared sacrifice. Leadership in putting executive power on the line and rallying the populace to react when small, petty people of both parties refuse to act in congress.

This situation could become dangerous. We need leadership equivalent to wartime to distribute the pain fairly and equitably.

I didn't vote for Obama. But I sure will this time. Not because he's been great (he's been good), but because he's our best shot.
Given the recent failure of Okun's law over the past few years, how can you credibly project rates with U?  Might as well use astrology.
The book series/movies and characters are part of our popular culture.  They're not just commercial products.  They're fair game for a crossword puzzle.

I think that that when it comes to the scoring of writing, subjectivity is unavoidable, and always has been.

Without a doubt, human essay scorers are inconsistent and often flawed in their approach. Some place too high a value on neat handwriting, others score essays more harshly when the theme of the essay is a subject that doesn't interest them. Others just hurry up and don't pay too much attention at all to what's said.

But honestly -- how can we talk about consistency when what we're really trying to "score" is ART? Take movie or book reviewers. Two very experienced and knowledgeable critics can take exactly the opposite view on the quality of the very same book or movie, and often do. One can hate it, one can love it, all for legitimate reasons. Who's wrong? Who's right? Both -- and neither.

Having said all this, and while fully acknowledging the fact that there's no such thing as a fully objective human reader, if I were the person taking the test, I'd STILL prefer that my work be read and scored by an human being, warts and all, instead by a soulless, emotionless machine that "thinks" in algorithms instead of fully formed ideas.

It goes back to the question of why we write at all, and thinking, while writing, about one's audience. In my view, if the audience isn't real, our voices can't be, either.
Even when an Israeli suggests that the country begin to withdraw, remove settlers, and give over land to the Palestinians, you react in anger.  This is precisely why Israel must act unilaterally.

"Israel never had and could never hope for a more compliant partner"?
You live in Michigan Mr Thompson? Obviously you have never received Qassam roquettes from you neighbour! You should keep in mind that Gaza is not Ontario, Canada! I am appalled by the lack of sympathy and understanding towards Israelis by American readers of the NYT. I can only see that as the result of this newspaper's pro-palestinian slant...We should be welcoming the quiet and peaceful viewpoint of people who actually live in Israel!

The history of Israel since 1948 is the story of an endless LAND GRAP campaign that started with the occupation of some 20% of the total area of Palestine BEYOND its UNGA land allocation in Partition of Palestine resolution.

That 20 % extra land constituted 40% of the Palestinian Arab state land allocation; its occupation precluded the establishment of a viable Palestinian state in 1948

Post 1967: the annexation of East Jerusalem + surroundings, Settlements, confiscation of Arab land under diverse pretexts ( including zoning it as a GREEN area then rezoning as Residential for Jews only etc) and the WALL ..
Both the USA and The NY Times seem to support the Wall and all lands WEST of the WALL as indisputably Israeli.

The Palestinian/Israeli conflict is PRIMARILY a conflict over LAND on which to establish a state to house people, relocate returning refugees, cultivate and produce the wherewithal of a decent life and viable society.

Israel supported by the USA, via political, financial and military support, is going all out to deprive the Palestinians of ANY LAND with the ultimate objective of driving them out from their homeland!

With its implicit support of major Settlements and now the WALL the USA, and The NY Times, are only fertilizing and watering a long term historical conflict that will reverberate NEGATIVELY on ALL!
That is CERTAINLY an ominous way to start negotiations meant to minimize Palestinan land with the unacceptable provisio of "East of the WALL."!

Israel frequently announced when building its Wall that it was not meant as a claim on land and was not the intended border. That is because it amounts to a very aggressive land grab. Now you calmly suggest it. That is a very aggressive land grab, not unilateral peace.

The problem for Israel was not a lack of trust. Israel never had and could never hope for a more compliant partner. The problem was that Israel's terms were so aggressive and extreme that even that partner could not accept them. You now suggest unilaterally backing off. That won't happen, because that is all that stood in the way all along. The problem has always been that Israel cannot stop taking more and more. A unilateral move backwards contradicts everything that has characterized Israel's behavior.

Your plan is essentially the only approach Israel has ever taken, creating facts on the ground meant to be permanent. That has never worked to bring peace. It never will. That is because peace must be agreed, it cannot be imposed, and it certainly cannot be imposed on the terms to taking everything you want and shoving the other side into the scraps, behind a Wall with violent guards.

What your propose is not peace, but another Gaza. That is not what anybody really wants.

In India today each and every religious day is marked with commerce .The auspicioius days of Hindu calender are not meant for meditation, introspection,empathy and kindness for others but for acquisition and gluttony.So the image that you have shown here is highlighting this very psychic by which Indian society is driven today.The marriage ceremony has also been commercialized with all the fanfare and at best represnts the vulgar disposition of wealth  of a family,individual and society as a whole.These are social evils which are dragging India to the past without even a semblance of modernity.Such practices pervade all castes,all religions acroos the economic divide.Most amazingly,  every body realizes these evils and curses one and other for the same, but none raises voice to abolish them.

Anita, that's a quandary that many of us struggle with. But your argument neglects benefits that make working financially worthwhile even when the take-home on its own seems paltry:

1. social security contributions

2. continued progress in one's career, usually accompanied by increased pay over the years (Unless Karen Hill's job was a dead end and her child stayed in daycare forever, she probably pocketed more than $10/week at some point.)

3. continued investment in one's workplace, which can become leverage for flexible schedules and/or telework arrangements, both of which can be difficult to negotiate when you are a new member of a team (Note that flex schedules and telework can reduce the need for daycare, and thus also have financial value in the above scenario.)

4. possible non-cash benefits, such as these currently enjoyed in some combination by most of my working friends: 401k matching contributions, free tuition for an advanced degree in one's field, use of company car, preferred admission and/or reduced tuition to a child's school, subsidized housing, discounted braces for a child, dental insurance, health insurance

Far be it for me to feel Mr. Brooks needs defending but I think you misspoke when you said "What it overlooks is that others can and will enter the market once it is created." You continue this line of argument for a full paragraph.

I think Mr. Brooks said just that when he wrote "everybody has to come to you if they want that service, at least for a time." He simply used fewer words.

This confuses capitalism and a market. Capitalism is private ownership. Market is competition setting terms of supply and demand. It is possible to have either without the other. We have both, in our ideal.

Monopoly works fine for us as a public utility. Otherwise, the market sets the qualities demanded and prices paid for them.

Your creative monopoly, creating a new niche instead of driving others out of an established niche, overlooks the market. That is an odd oversight for one of your proclivities.

What it overlooks is that others can and will enter the market once it is created. Unless, that is, they are kept out of it by monopoly practices which are and ought to be illegal here. All a new venture can do is be first, and take some big initial gains. It cannot keep to itself the new spot in the market it creates. It is a passing advantage. Plenty of companies exemplify how that has worked over the last couple of decades, rising fast and falling fast as others outdo them in the field they created. Look at just computer manufacturers, software design companies, and online service providers for new ideas that went big, then were outdone.

This does work well for all of us. But it is competitive, and it is market, not monopoly. All efforts to keep a market position free of competitors are that bad kind of monopoly you mentioned.

Eh Steve,

First, we start with a simple set up of 3 planets in a row. We'll call them Planets A, B and C. All the planets are the same size (it doesn't matter if they are the same size, but it is easier to imagine). The surface areas of the planets are each 4 pi r^2.

Imagine connecting each planet to its neighbor with a cylinder -- like the kind in the middle of a paper towel roll. It should fit tightly so that it just covers a hemisphere. Thus, the middle planet is completely covered by the two cylinders and the outer planets are only half covered.

Next we perturb the middle Planet B. The centers of all three planets will now form a triangle. The cylinders between the planets (we now have a new cylinder between the two end Planets A and C) will have as a center line the line between the centers of the two planets it connects. (This is an important conceptual idea).

At Planet A, there is now an angle BAC formed by the Planets. The cylinder from B to A will now make visible on Plant A a wedge with the surface area of 4 pi r^2 * (BAC/360°). The same amount on Planet B will now be made invisible. This is because they make they are a pair of angles between parallel lines. On Planet B, the newly exposed area is a wedge between the our now angled cylinder and a plane running through the center of Planet B and perpendicular to the original center line of the row of Planets.

(cont.)
Having had shingles, I recommend you get checked out asap. No matter what, they are very uncomfortable.

(cont).

Now, if we had perturbed our last Planet C the same amount as Planet B, it would be game over since the cylinder between Planets B and C had no effect on the newly exposed surface. However, since we kept Planet C on the same line, it will now form an angle ACB. Working through the same methodology, we can show that the newly made visible area on Planet C is 4 pi r^2 * (BAC/360°) which is the same amount now made invisible on Planet B.

You can expand this methodology with increasing difficulty to larger numbers of planets, and with tweaking to a mixed sized planets. And you can generalize it to an n-body problem.
....and all nicely held aloft in balance by the author at the base.
